Name the following things based on clues about their appearance in paintings. One of these objects comes out of a living room fireplace in the Rene Magritte painting Time Transfixed, and one moves towards the viewer in J.M.W. Turner's painting Rain, Steam, and Speed.

definition: Answer the following about performers of classical music. Yehudi Menuhin gave his violin to this other Israeli violinist, who also was once conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.
Answer the following about performers of classical music. This Catalan cellist made prominent recordings of various cello works by J.S. Bach, as well as many other cello sonatas and concerti.
term: Pablo Casals (kah-SAHLZ) [or Pau Casals i Defillo]

definition: Answer the following about performers of classical music. Peter Tchaikovsky's (chye-KOFF-skeez) first concerto for this instrument was written for Nikolai Rubinstein, who severely criticized it, which led Hans von Bulow to premiere it in his stead. A player of this instrument from Texas won the first International Tchaikovsky Competition for this instrument in 1958. Holocaust survivor Wladyslaw Szpilman (VWAH-dis-wahf SHPEEL-mahn) was a practitioner of this instrument, which was also played by Van Cliburn and Leonard Bernstein. A 2002 Roman Polanski film centered on a title musician who played what instrument that has 88 black and white keys?

Name these American artists. Amid the Battle of Quebec, a Native American sits in a pose reminiscent of Rodin's The Thinker in the best known work by this colonial-era artist who also painted Pennˈs Treaty with the Indians.
Name these American artists. Five paintings comprise the Course of Empire series created by this 19th century artist whose other notable works include The Titan's Goblet and The Oxbow.

Name these American artists. An impending hilltop collision between a car and red truck is the subject of this artist's painting Death on Ridge Road. One painting by this artist depicts a tall church being passed by a galloping horse, while another of his works shows three old ladies standing in front of a copy of Emanuel Leutze's (LOYT-zuhz) Washington Crossing the Delaware. Those paintings are The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere and Daughters of Revolution. The Dibble House is portrayed in his best known work, which depicts two figures modeled after this artist's sister Nan and his dentist Byron McKeeby. Name this Iowa native who shows a bespectacled farmer holding a pitchfork in his 1930 painting American Gothic.

Answer the following questions about repeated notes in music. This contemporary minimalist composer, who teamed with the Kronos Quartet on the album Salome Dances for Peace, is best known for the composition, In C, in which a piano plays the highest C key throughout the entire piece, with the other musicians playing a set of phrases in undefined intervals.

Answer the following questions about repeated notes in music. The pianist plays a repeated A flat through this piece, except for a brief section in C sharp minor where the repeated note is a B instead. It was composed in 1839 and is the longest of its composer's twenty-four preludes.

Answer the following questions about repeated notes in music. In the second movement of a piece by this composer, a B flat octave is played constantly by the pianist to imitate a bell that tolls over a scene depicting an executed man. A quote by Henri de Regnier (ren-YAY) is placed at the top of a piano piece by this composer that depicts ˈˈwater games.ˈˈ He wrote a piece for piano that includes ˈˈLe Gibetˈˈ (ZHEE- bay), which is followed by ˈˈScarboˈˈ, a movement intended to be more difficult than Mily Balakirev's Islamey. In another piece by this composer of Jeux d'eau (zhuh doo) and Gaspard de la Nuit (nwee), two melodies are passed around the orchestra on top of an ostinato rhythm from the snare drum. Name this late 19th and early 20th century French composer who wrote Bolero.

Name these composers who were inspired or used themes by Ludwig van Beethoven. This composer quoted the G-G-G-E flat motif in Beethoven's fifth symphony throughout each movement of his Concord Sonata. He also composed Three Places in New England.

Name these composers who were inspired or used themes by Ludwig van Beethoven. Hans von Bulow called this composer's first symphony ˈˈBeethoven's Tenthˈˈ, in part because the theme of its final movement resembles that of the Choral Symphony.

Name these composers who were inspired or used themes by Ludwig van Beethoven. The theme from the funeral march of Beethoven's Eroica Symphony is quoted near the end of a piece this composer wrote for 23 strings. A wind machine, thunder machine, and twenty horns are part of the score for a tone poem by this composer that has twenty-two sections. In another tone poem by this man, a horn motif depicts the title trickster. Another piece by this composer of Metamorphosen and An Alpine Symphony features a violin solo in its section ˈˈThe Dance Song.ˈˈ This composer's most famous tone poem ends with the orchestra playing a B and C simultaneously, and that work opens with the trumpet playing a rising C-G-C motif. Name this German composer of Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks and Also Sprach Zarathustra.
term: Richard Georg Strauss (REEK-hart shtrouse) [prompt on ˈˈStraussˈˈ]

definition: Name the following artists of paintings depicting horses. This Swiss-born painter depicted a horse peering its head through a curtain while an incubus sits on the chest of a sleeping woman in his best known painting, The Nightmare.

Name the following artists of paintings depicting horses. A white horse is stabbed in the chest while its bloodied rider is being pulled off head-first in this artist's painting The Charge of the Mamelukes, which was inspired by a rebellion against French troops.
term: Francisco Jose de Goya y Lucientes

definition: Name the following artists of paintings depicting horses. One painting by this artist depicts several horses being held by their handlers behind a rope just before the start of a race in the Italian capital. This artist of Riderless Racers at Rome depicted four horses mid-stride during the title event in his painting The 1821 Derby at Epsom. A ˈˈman suffering from delusions of military rankˈˈ was the subject of one of his paintings from a series of portraits of mental asylum patients that also included Portrait of a Kleptomaniac. In his best known painting, a barely-visible ship named the Argus draws the attention of several people, including a black man who waves a red cloth while standing atop a barrel. The aftermath of an 1816 shipwreck is the subject of the best known work by what early 19th century French artist who painted The Raft of the Medusa?

Name these 20th century paintings. Two women wearing similar hats sit across a table from one another in this Edward Hopper painting, in which the sign for the title restaurant is partially visible through a window on the right side.

Name these 20th century paintings. The words ˈˈI pressed the fire control...and ahead of me rockets blazed through the skyˈˈ appear in this Roy Lichtenstein painting, which features the title written out directly above an airplane that is experiencing a fiery explosion.

Name these 20th century paintings. The words ˈˈbeautiful world of cottages / of the night and of fieldsˈˈ begin a poem that accompanied this painting at its first exhibition; that poem was written by Paul Eluard. An early version of this painting depicted one figure weeping blood-colored tears, as well as a raised hand holding stalks of grain against the backdrop of a shining sun. The bottom left corner of this painting depicts the palm of a hand with the stigmata. At the top of this painting, one figure holds a lit candle next to a shining light bulb that hangs over the head of a horse. A flower sprouts out of a dismembered arm that holds a shattered sword in this painting, which features a bull standing above a grieving woman holding a dead child. Name this 1937 painting by Pablo Picasso that was created in response to a Nazi bombing of the title Spanish city.

Answer the following about Baroque music. Arcangelo Corelli is most famous today for his set of compositions of this type, which includes one nicknamed ˈˈChristmas.ˈˈ They are distinctive for having multiple solo parts.
Answer the following about Baroque music. One of the most influential choral pieces written during the Baroque era was a mass by Johann Sebastian Bach that was written in this key.
term: B minor [do not accept ˈˈBˈˈ or ˈˈB majorˈˈ or any answer mentioning ˈˈB flatˈˈ]

definition: Answer the following about Baroque music. Scoring changes for this piece over the last few centuries, such as those by Ebenezer Prout and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, have continually added woodwinds and brass, while in English-speaking countries it was performed with increasingly large choirs. The only two sections of this piece solely for orchestra are the opening ˈˈSinfonyˈˈ and a ˈˈPifaˈˈ that introduces the Annunciation to the Shepherds. A common tradition started by British King George II (the second) is to stand during one section of this composition; that section concludes its second of three parts and includes the lines ˈˈand he shall reign for ever and ever.ˈˈ Name this oratorio by Georg Frideric Handel that contains the ˈˈHallelujahˈˈ chorus.

Name these European artists. This early 18th century French painter is best known for depicting several cupids flying above a large group of people walking along the countryside in his painting The Embarkation for Cythera.

Name these European artists. This 20th century Swiss-born painter who taught at the Bauhaus (rhymes with ˈˈcow houseˈˈ) is best known for depicting four stick figure birds on a wire in his painting Twittering Machine.

Name these European artists. In the bottom right corner of one painting by this artist, several arrows lie on the ground next to the title nude figure, who turns his back toward the viewer while seated on a red cloth. Another work by this artist of Patroclus depicts Cupid and the Three Graces taking away several items belonging to the title god, who is distracted by the title goddess; that work is Mars Being Disarmed by Venus. Pope Pius VII (the seventh) was the subject of a portrait by this artist, who painted a work showing the title figure holding a quill pen in one hand while the other holds a letter featuring the name Charlotte Corday. Another of his works shows three Roman brothers saluting their father, who holds three swords. Name this Neoclassical French artist of The Death of Marat and Oath of the Horatii.

Answer the following about compositions that require an unusual set of instruments. This piece in eight movements was written while its composer, Olivier Messiaen (oh-LIV-ee-ay meh-SYAWN), was imprisoned in a World War 2 POW camp. It was scored for violin, cello, clarinet, and piano.
term: Quartet for the End of Time [or Quatuor pour la fin du temps]

definition: Answer the following about compositions that require an unusual set of instruments. One of Bela Bartok's most famous compositions is a 1937 work titled Music for Strings, Percussion and [this instrument].

Answer the following about compositions that require an unusual set of instruments. This composer wrote a piece with six movements that all have titles from verses of the Song of Solomon, and that piece features a wordless choir and solo viola despite not being a concerto. He used poems from Leaves of Grass for the text to his first symphony, whose last movement is titled ˈˈThe Explorers.ˈˈ This composer wrote a piece for solo violin based off a George Meredith poem. This composer of Flos Campi wrote a piece scored for two differently-sized orchestras and a string quartet. Name this British composer who wrote A Sea Symphony, The Lark Ascending, and Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis.
term: Ralph (rafe) Vaughan Williams [prompt on partial answer]

definition: Name these painters active in the 16th century. This German member of the Danube School is best known for depicting a 333 B.C. conflict in the 1529 painting The Battle of Alexander at Issus.
Name these painters active in the 16th century. This Italian painter is best known for depicting a breastfeeding woman being watched by a man next to a small stream in the 1508 painting The Tempest.

Name these painters active in the 16th century. On the bottom right corner of one painting by this artist, a boy holds a waffle in each hand while several people around him cut and gather firewood from leafless trees. That painting, The Gloomy Day, is part of his Labors of the Months series. Another painting by this artist shows four men with canes following two others ahead of them who have fallen down. This artist of The Blind Leading the Blind depicted desolation caused by an army of skeletons in The Triumph of Death. One painting by this artist depicts part of the title, Biblical structure obscured by a cloud; another of his paintings depicts two figures carrying food on an unhinged door during the title celebration. Name this Flemish painter of The Tower of Babel and The Peasant Wedding.
term: Pieter Brueghel (BROY-gul) the Elder [do not accept ˈˈJan Brueghelˈˈ or ˈˈPieter Brueghel the Youngerˈˈ]

definition: Name these paintings featuring many people. A man prepares to sink a knife into the neck of a nude woman in the bottom right corner of this Eugene Delacroix painting, in which the title figure looks on from a bed while a woman begs at his feet.
term: Death of Sardanapalus [or La Mort de Sardanapale]

definition: Name these paintings featuring many people. Two women hold white cloths to their face behind the dog that appears in this Gustave Courbet painting, in which one figure holds a crucifix next to the man who is directing the title event.
term: A Burial at Ornans [or A Funeral at Ornans or Une interrement a Ornans]

definition: Name these paintings featuring many people. On the right side of this painting, a man writes in a book while standing on one foot and leaning against a wall; that man stands below a statue that depicts Athena holding her shield with the head of Medusa. In the middle of this painting, a bearded old man reads from a piece of paper while sitting on a staircase. This painting is located in a room with three other works by the same artist, two of which are The Parnassus and La Disputa. On its right side, a bent over man uses a compass to draw on a chalkboard next to two other men who hold spheres. The books Timaeus and Nicomachean Ethics are held by the central figures of this fresco, which depicts Averroes standing next to Pythagoras. Plato and Aristotle walk among many ancient philosophers in what Vatican fresco by Raphael?
term: The School of Athens [or Scuola di Atene]

definition: Name these musical forms and types of pieces. Johann Sebastian Bach wrote a piece titled the ˈˈArt ofˈˈ this musical form, which uses multiple voices and counterpoint to develop a stated theme.
Name these musical forms and types of pieces. Pieces of this type are written as exercises in improving specific techniques. Liszt wrote some difficult-to-play ˈˈTranscendentalˈˈ ones.

Name these musical forms and types of pieces. Camille Saint-Saens' (caa-meel san-sahnss-iz) fifth composition in this genre includes a theme inspired by one he heard while sailing on the Nile River, leading to its nickname of ˈˈEgyptian.ˈˈ Dmitri Shostakovich wrote two pieces in this genre, the first of which includes an extensive solo part for trumpet. Peter Tchaikovsky's first piece of this type, written in B flat minor, opens with a descending fanfare in the horns. Maurice Ravel wrote a piece of this type that opens with a whipcrack. Edvard Grieg's only composition of this type begins with a timpani roll and is in A minor. Ludwig van Beethoven wrote five of these compositions, the last of which is nicknamed ˈˈEmperor.ˈˈ Name this type of piece for solo keyboard instrument and orchestra.
